description: Fundamental positions that provide balance, power, and stability for all Taekwondo techniques.

safety: Maintain proper knee alignment over feet
Avoid locking knees in any stance

techniques.description: Basic standing position with feet together, ready for action
techniques.detailedDescription: The fundamental ready position where feet are together, hands at sides, and body is alert. Used for bowing and beginning/ending patterns.
techniques.application: Starting position for all patterns, formal greetings, and mental preparation before technique execution.
steps: Stand with heels together, feet at 45-degree angle
Keep hands naturally at sides with fingers straight
Maintain straight back and relaxed shoulders
Focus eyes forward with determined expression
Keep weight evenly distributed on both feet
commonMistakes: Feet too far apart or uneven

techniques.description: Feet shoulder-width apart, parallel to each other
techniques.detailedDescription: A stable standing position with feet parallel and shoulder-width apart. Provides solid base for various techniques.
techniques.application: Foundation for basic techniques, ready position for some patterns, and stable platform for power generation.
steps: Place feet shoulder-width apart, parallel to each other
Distribute weight evenly on both feet
Bend knees slightly for stability
Keep back straight and shoulders relaxed
Position hands in ready position or guarding block
commonMistakes: Feet too narrow or too wide
Weight on heels or toes only

techniques.description: Parallel stance with specific hand positioning for readiness
techniques.detailedDescription: A prepared version of parallel stance with hands positioned for immediate technique execution. Shows mental and physical readiness.
techniques.application: Ready position for patterns and techniques, demonstrates preparedness for action.
steps: Assume parallel stance with feet shoulder-width apart
Bring hands up to chest level, palms facing each other
Keep elbows slightly bent and relaxed
Maintain alert posture with focused expression
Be prepared to move in any direction immediately
commonMistakes: Hands too high or too low

techniques.description: Deep stance with wide base, knees bent outward
techniques.detailedDescription: A powerful, stable stance with wide foot placement and deep knee bend. Provides excellent stability for strong techniques.
techniques.application: Used for powerful blocks, strikes, and developing leg strength. Common in many patterns.
steps: Place feet two shoulder-widths apart
Turn feet slightly outward at 25-degree angle
Bend knees deeply, keeping them over feet
Keep back straight and perpendicular to ground
Distribute weight evenly between both feet
commonMistakes: Feet too narrow or too wide

techniques.description: Sitting stance with ready hand positioning
techniques.detailedDescription: The prepared version of sitting stance, combining the stability of deep stance with readiness for immediate action.
techniques.application: Ready position for techniques requiring power and stability, often used in pattern beginnings.
steps: Assume proper sitting stance position
Position hands in ready posture at chest level
Keep elbows slightly bent and relaxed
Maintain deep, stable base with straight back
Focus eyes forward with determined expression
commonMistakes: Stance too shallow for ready position
Poor alignment of knees and feet

techniques.description: Forward-facing stance with 70% weight on front leg
techniques.detailedDescription: A dynamic, forward-oriented stance ideal for attacking techniques. Provides strong forward momentum and balance.
techniques.application: Primary stance for forward attacks, punches, and front kicks. Used extensively in patterns.
steps: Step forward with one foot, shoulder-width apart
Bend front knee to align with ankle
Keep back leg straight with foot at 25-degree angle
Distribute weight: 70% front, 30% back
Keep hips and shoulders square to front
commonMistakes: Stance too long or too short

techniques.description: Walking stance prepared for immediate action
techniques.detailedDescription: The ready version of walking stance, positioned for quick forward movement and technique execution.
techniques.application: Ready position for forward-attacking techniques and patterns requiring immediate forward motion.
steps: Assume proper walking stance position
Position hands in ready posture appropriate for technique
Keep body weight slightly forward for quick movement
Maintain alert, focused posture
Be prepared to execute techniques immediately
commonMistakes: Hands not in proper ready position
Weight too far back for quick forward movement
Stance too deep for quick transitions

techniques.description: Side-facing stance with feet in L-shape, weight distributed 50/50
techniques.detailedDescription: A versatile side-facing stance providing excellent mobility and defensive positioning. Feet form an L-shape with even weight distribution.
techniques.application: Used for defensive techniques, side kicks, and creating angles against opponents.
steps: Place feet in L-shape, one foot forward, one perpendicular
Keep distance of one shoulder-width between feet
Bend both knees equally, weight 50/50 distribution
Align front knee with front foot, back knee with back foot
Keep hips and shoulders at 45-degree angle to front
commonMistakes: Feet too close or too far apart
Hips squared to front instead of angled

techniques.description: L-stance prepared for immediate defensive or offensive action
techniques.detailedDescription: The ready version of L-stance, positioned for quick angular movement and technique execution from side-facing position.
techniques.application: Ready position for angular attacks, defensive techniques, and patterns requiring side-facing readiness.
steps: Assume proper L-stance position
Position hands for angular technique execution
Maintain 50/50 weight distribution for quick movement
Keep body alert to both front and side directions
Be prepared for quick angular transitions
commonMistakes: Stance too rigid for quick movement

techniques.description: Very deep, wide stance for maximum stability and power
techniques.detailedDescription: An extremely deep and wide stance designed for maximum stability and power generation. Used for powerful techniques requiring solid base.
techniques.application: Powerful breaking techniques, strong defensive positions, and developing exceptional leg strength.
steps: Place feet very wide, beyond shoulder-width
Bend knees deeply until thighs are nearly parallel to ground
Keep back straight and vertical
Distribute weight evenly between both feet
Turn feet outward at 45-degree angles
commonMistakes: Weight on toes instead of whole foot
Feet too narrow for proper stability

techniques.description: Feet together with specific hand positioning variation A
techniques.detailedDescription: A closed stance with feet together and specific hand positioning (variation A) used in advanced patterns and formal ready positions.
techniques.application: Formal ready position for advanced patterns, demonstrates precision and control in technique preparation.
steps: Bring feet together with heels touching
Position hands in specific pattern-ready position A
Keep back straight and shoulders relaxed
Maintain alert, focused posture
Be prepared for immediate pattern execution
commonMistakes: Hand position incorrect for variation A

techniques.description: Bent-knee ready stance variation A for dynamic techniques
techniques.detailedDescription: A ready stance with bent knees and specific hand positioning (variation A) designed for quick, dynamic technique execution.
techniques.application: Ready position for dynamic, flowing techniques and patterns requiring quick weight transfers.
steps: Assume position with knees comfortably bent
Position hands in bending ready variation A
Keep weight on balls of feet for quick movement
Maintain relaxed but alert upper body
Be prepared for rapid technique execution
commonMistakes: Knees too bent or too straight
Weight on heels instead of balls of feet
Hand position incorrect for variation A

techniques.description: Cross-legged stance for quick direction changes and agility
techniques.detailedDescription: A dynamic, cross-legged stance used for quick direction changes, spinning techniques, and demonstrating advanced balance and agility.
techniques.application: Spinning techniques, quick direction changes, and advanced pattern movements requiring cross-legged stability.
steps: Cross one leg behind the other
Keep feet close together, one supporting most weight
Bend supporting knee slightly for stability
Keep upper body upright and balanced
Be prepared to uncross quickly for movement
commonMistakes: Feet too far apart in cross position
Cross position too deep for quick movement

techniques.description: Closed stance with advanced hand positioning variation B
techniques.detailedDescription: Advanced closed ready stance with specific hand positioning (variation B) used in high-level patterns and demonstrating precision readiness.
techniques.application: Formal ready position for advanced patterns, demonstrates mastery of stance precision and control.
steps: Bring feet together with precise alignment
Position hands in specific pattern-ready position B
Maintain perfect posture and balance
Demonstrate mental and physical readiness
Be prepared for complex pattern execution
commonMistakes: Hand position incorrect for variation B

techniques.description: Stance with most weight on rear foot for defensive positioning
techniques.detailedDescription: A defensive-oriented stance with majority of weight on rear foot, allowing for quick backward movement and counter-attacks.
techniques.application: Defensive techniques, creating distance from opponents, and preparing for counter-attacking moves.
steps: Position feet in walking stance configuration
Shift weight 90% to rear foot, 10% on front
Keep front foot touching lightly for balance
Maintain body alignment for quick backward movement
Be prepared for defensive techniques
commonMistakes: Front foot bearing too much weight
Stance too deep for quick backward motion

techniques.description: Exceptionally deep stance for maximum power and stability
techniques.detailedDescription: An extremely low version of basic stances, demonstrating advanced leg strength, balance, and power generation capability.
techniques.application: Maximum power techniques, advanced breaking, and demonstrations of exceptional physical conditioning.
steps: Assume basic stance (sitting or walking)
Lower body exceptionally deep while maintaining form
Keep back straight and vertical despite depth
Maintain proper knee and foot alignment
Demonstrate control and stability in deep position
commonMistakes: Form breaking due to excessive depth

techniques.description: Master-level closed ready stance with variation C hand positioning
techniques.detailedDescription: The most advanced closed ready stance variation, demonstrating master-level precision, control, and readiness for complex techniques.
techniques.application: Ready position for master-level patterns, demonstrates ultimate control and preparation for advanced technique execution.
steps: Achieve perfect foot-together alignment
Execute precise hand positioning variation C
Demonstrate complete physical and mental control
Maintain perfect balance and posture
Exhibit master-level readiness and focus
commonMistakes: Hand position not precisely variation C

techniques.description: Advanced stance emphasizing perfect vertical alignment and balance
techniques.detailedDescription: A master-level stance focusing on perfect vertical alignment from head through feet, demonstrating ultimate balance and body control.
techniques.application: Advanced patterns requiring perfect alignment, demonstrations of master-level balance, and techniques demanding absolute precision.
steps: Achieve perfect vertical alignment throughout body
Maintain exact 90-degree angles where required
Demonstrate complete balance and stability
Exhibit control over every body segment
Show master-level understanding of body mechanics
commonMistakes: Any deviation from perfect vertical alignment
